G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28 and related statu.proposition: NOW COMES the Plaintiff, Rachel Bennett, and respectfully submits this Complaint for Modification of the current custody and parenting time arrangements with respect to the minor child of the parties, Sophie Carter, pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 and related statutes.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter under G.L. c. 209C, § 20 and G.L. c. 208, § 28.

*See Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 M.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, the standard for modification of a custody order is demonstrating that a material and substantial change in circumstances has occurred, and that the modification is necessary in the child's best interests. *See Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985); *Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App. Ct. 239, 244 (2015).
*See Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 M.support_reasoning: Yannas does not involve a post-judgment modification standard; it is an initial divorce/custody and removal decision. The opinion frames the governing question for removal in terms of the child’s best interests and the custodial parent’s ‘real advantage,’ not in terms of a ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ plus best interests. The ‘material and substantial change’ formulation comes from later Massachusetts modification cases, not from Yannas.
*See Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 M.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents who is a native of . . . this commonwealth . . . shall not, if of suitable age to signify his consent, be removed out of this commonwealth without such consent, or, if under that age, without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815) …”}

*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, the standard for modification of a custody order is demonstrating that a material and substantial change in circumstances has occurred, and that the modification is necessary in the child's best interests. *See Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985); *Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App. Ct. 239, 244 (2015).
*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..support_reasoning: Schechter discusses standards for initial custody determinations and for removal under G.L. c. 208, § 30, but it does not articulate or apply the standard for modification of an existing custody order. The opinion focuses on best interests, abuse presumptions, and removal (‘upon cause shown’/real advantage), not on the ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ requirement for modifying custody. Thus, it does not support the specific modification standard stated in the proposition.
*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: “In Massachusetts the focus in a custody dispute between parents is not on their personal rights but on the welfare of the child… ‘[i]n deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare.’ … The statutory standard of ‘upon cause shown’ means that removal must be in the best interests of the child. Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985).”

*See Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App..raw_text: *See Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257, 261 (2001)
*See Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App..proposition: The Defendant's move to New Hampshire and the associated increased distance between the parents’ homes constitute a significant material change in circumstances. *See Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257, 261 (2001).
*See Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The opinion holds that a custodial parent’s relocation cannot itself be the material and substantial change justifying a custody modification; it must be based on other circumstances. The court explicitly rejects treating the move (and its consequences, such as changed living arrangements) as the qualifying change in circumstances. The case therefore does not support the proposition that moving to another state and the associated increased distance between homes constitutes a significant material change in circumstances; it stands for the opposite.
*See Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: “Our decision today, that a request for modification of custody is distinct from a request to relocate and must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances other than the move, is consistent with these decisions and with G. L. c. 208, § 28… The probate judge found… ‘[b]ecause Caleb spends the majority of his week in Northboro… most of his activities take place there.’ This was a change in Caleb’s living arrangments brought about solely as a consequence of the mother’s compliance with the August 25 order… [and] cannot form the basis upon which a final judgment modifying custody is granted.”}

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: The best interests of the child are the paramount standard in all custody and parenting time adjudications.

*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 494 (20.proposition: The best interests of the child are the paramount standard in all custody and parenting time adjudications. *G.L. c. 208, § 31*; *Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 494 (2012).
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 494 (20.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly frames custody determinations around the best interests of the child, describing that standard as the central inquiry and tying it to G.L. c. 208, § 31. While the case involves a specific custody dispute, the court states the best-interests test in general terms applicable to custody matters, so it fairly supports the proposition that this is the paramount standard in custody and parenting time adjudications.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 494 (20.relevant_excerpt: “Parents have an equal right to custody of their children. See Commonwealth v. Beals, 405 Mass. 550, 554 (1989). ‘In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is] . . . what is “best for the child” . . . .’ Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840 (2003). … The judge shall consider ‘whether or not the child’s present or past living conditions adversely affect his physical, mental, moral or emotional health.’ G. L. c. 208, § 31.”

*See Ardizoni v. Raymond*, 40 Mass. App..raw_text: *See Ardizoni v. Raymond*, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734, 738 (1996)
*See Ardizoni v. Raymond*, 40 Mass. App..proposition: It is well established that parenting plans must be realistic, conducive to maintaining continuity in the child’s education, and supportive of the child’s emotional and physical health. *See Ardizoni v. Raymond*, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734, 738 (1996).
*See Ardizoni v. Raymond*, 40 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The case concerns modification of custody and emphasizes that decisions must be guided by the children’s best interests, including a presumption favoring keeping siblings together and caution in weighing children’s expressed preferences. It does not articulate any general standard that “parenting plans must be realistic, conducive to maintaining continuity in the child’s education, and supportive of the child’s emotional and physical health.” Those specific elements of the proposition do not appear in, nor are they clearly derived from, the court’s reasoning in Ardizoni, so the citation overstates what the case holds.
*See Ardizoni v. Raymond*, 40 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: “When determining child custody awards in general, or modifications of custody awards based on changed circumstances, the guiding principle always has been the best interests of the children. … The list of factors within the judge’s purview in child custody matters includes a presumption generally favoring the placement of siblings under one roof. … Statements of a particular preference, however, ‘must be treated with caution’… [T]he preference of a younger child ‘is not given decisive weight.’”

*See Altomare v. Altomare*, 77 Mass. App.raw_text: *See Altomare v. Altomare*, 77 Mass. App. Ct. 601, 607 (2010)
*See Altomare v. Altomare*, 77 Mass. App.proposition: Forcing a 9-year-old child to endure long drives during the school week is contrary to her educational and emotional well-being, particularly where it results in diminished participation in extracurricular activities, interrupted sleep, and increased anxiety. *See Altomare v. Altomare*, 77 Mass. App. Ct. 601, 607 (2010).
*See Altomare v. Altomare*, 77 Mass. App.support_reasoning: The opinion does not make any finding that long weekday drives for a 9‑year‑old (or any specific age) are contrary to the child’s educational or emotional well-being, nor does it discuss interrupted sleep, anxiety, or diminished extracurricular participation as a legal or factual conclusion. The only discussion of driving time is in the context of evaluating the practicality of the mother’s proposed visitation schedule as part of the relocation/best-interests analysis, and the court explicitly states it is “unclear” what impact the early morning ride would have on the children. Thus, the case does not establish the specific child‑welfare proposition for which it is cited.
*See Altomare v. Altomare*, 77 Mass. App.relevant_excerpt: “The judge found: ‘Plaintiff proposes to have the children spend one night a week with the defendant; she would drive them to Worcester the night before and pick them up the next morning to bring them to school. This would involve about a three hour round trip by her twice in twelve hours, and two hour and a half trips for the children in that time period. It would take each of them out of their school and extracurricular activities one afternoon/ evening each week. … It is unclear what impact the early morning ride would have on the children.’”

*See Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. C.raw_text: *See Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 349, 354 (2006)
*See Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. C.proposition: Courts have consistently modified parenting orders based on geographic relocations that require significant adjustments to ensure the child’s routine and stability are prioritized. *See Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 349, 354 (2006); *Hewitt v. Hewitt*, 74 Mass. App. Ct. 1116 (2009) (unpublished).
*See Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. C.support_reasoning: The opinion in Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 349 (2006), as reproduced here, is a criminal case dealing with murder, motions for a new trial, missing witness instructions, investigative funds, and ineffective assistance of counsel. It does not concern family law, custody, parenting plans, relocation, or modification of parenting orders. Therefore, it cannot support a proposition about courts modifying parenting orders due to geographic relocation and child stability; the citation is inapposite to that proposition.
*See Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. C.relevant_excerpt: On consolidated appeals from his convictions of murder in the second degree, G. L. c. 265, § 1, and related crimes, and from the denial of his motions for a new trial and for funds for an investigator, the defendant argues that the Commonwealth misrepresented that an eyewitness to the crimes was unavailable, thereby depriving him of a missing witness instruction, and that trial counsel’s failure to call an alleged exculpatory witness constituted ineffective assistance.

*Hewitt v. Hewitt*, 74 Mass. App. Ct. 11.proposition: Courts have consistently modified parenting orders based on geographic relocations that require significant adjustments to ensure the child’s routine and stability are prioritized. *See Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 349, 354 (2006); *Hewitt v. Hewitt*, 74 Mass. App. Ct. 1116 (2009) (unpublished).
